content.description: Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder (OCPD) is a pervasive pattern of preoccupation with orderliness, perfectionism, and control, at the expense of flexibility, openness, and efficiency. Unlike OCD, it does not require intrusive obsessions or compulsions and is ego-syntonic, with individuals often viewing their behavior as appropriate or advantageous.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A pervasive pattern of preoccupation with orderliness, perfectionism, and mental and interpersonal control, at the expense of flexibility, openness, and efficiency, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by ≥4 of: (1) Preoccupation with details, rules, lists, order, organization, or schedules to the extent that the major point is lost; (2) Perfectionism that interferes with task completion; (3) Excessive devotion to work and productivity to the exclusion of leisure and friendships; (4) Overconscientious, scrupulous, and inflexible about matters of morality, ethics, or values; (5) Unable to discard worn-out or worthless objects even without sentimental value; (6) Reluctant to delegate tasks unless others submit exactly to their way; (7) Adopts a miserly spending style toward self and others; (8) Shows rigidity and stubbornness.
content.prevalence: Estimated 2–8% in the general population; more common in men.
content.age_of_onset: Early adulthood, with traits often beginning in adolescence.
content.prognosis: Chronic but can improve with therapy and increased flexibility. Risk of depression or anxiety when perfectionism is unmet or challenged.

circuitry: Possible involvement of prefrontal and anterior cingulate regions linked to cognitive control and error monitoring.
neurochemistry: Limited direct evidence; possible serotonergic involvement.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Moderate heritability; often associated with high conscientiousness, authoritarian parenting, and environments emphasizing rules and perfection.

history_psychosocial: Patterns of rigidity, perfectionism, and work habits across settings.
Impact on relationships and adaptability in changing environments.
medical_assessment: Screen for comorbid anxiety, depression, and other personality disorders.
standardized_measures: Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 Personality Disorders (SCID-5-PD).
risk_stratification: High stress when rules or standards cannot be maintained; risk of burnout.
evaluation.team_and_process: Long-term psychotherapy focusing on cognitive flexibility, interpersonal functioning, and reducing perfectionism.

emotional: Anxiety when things are out of order
behavioral: Overworking at the expense of relationships

severity_levels.mild: Perfectionism with minimal impairment; able to adapt in some situations.
severity_levels.moderate: Frequent conflict in work or relationships due to rigidity.
severity_levels.severe: Marked impairment across domains; inability to function without strict adherence to rules and standards.

psychological: Insecure attachment with control as a coping strategy

impact_on_life.school_work: Difficulty delegating; projects delayed by perfectionism.
impact_on_life.social: Strained relationships due to control and inflexibility.
impact_on_life.emotional: Chronic tension, irritability, and low enjoyment.

psychotherapy: CBT targeting perfectionism and cognitive flexibility.
Schema therapy to address control and rigidity patterns.
medications: SSRIs if comorbid anxiety or depression is present.
lifestyle_interventions: Structured leisure activities to counter overwork.
care_coordination: Psychoeducation for family on supporting flexibility and reducing conflict.

missed_diagnosis_factors: Confusing high conscientiousness with pathological rigidity.
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling cultural or occupational perfectionism as OCPD.
warning_signs: Escalating conflict over minor rule violations
self_help_strategies: Practice flexibility through small, controlled changes.
Set time limits for tasks to avoid overrefinement.

adolescence: Emerging rigidity in schoolwork; limited leisure.
adulthood: Established perfectionistic work style; strained relationships.

real_life_examples: A 35-year-old accountant spends excessive hours perfecting reports, leading to burnout and marital strain; improves after CBT for perfectionism.
content.when_to_seek_help: When perfectionism and rigidity consistently cause distress, burnout, or relationship problems.

positive_factors: Insight into the costs of rigidity
